quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrong‚Äîthat's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: Midway through your high-altitude climbing expedition, three issues emerge: (1) Your lead climber reports persistent shortness of breath due to altitude‚Äînot a blocker yet, but could become critical if ignored; (2) A supply shipment from base camp has been delayed by 5 days, meaning you might run low on oxygen canisters in 3 days; (3) Two team members have developed friction over camp duties, reducing team morale slightly but not affecting current climbing progress.
quickScenarioChallenge.question: As expedition manager, which issue should you address with IMMEDIATE action?

options.A: The altitude sickness concern‚Äîmonitor the climber closely and adjust ascent schedule
options.B: The supply shortage‚Äîescalate to base camp and implement contingency plan immediately
options.C: The team friction‚Äîhold a mediation session to restore morale
options.D: All three equally‚Äîtackle them simultaneously in parallel

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Supply shortage (time-critical, affects mission viability)

insights.principle: Impact vs. Urgency in Issue Management
insights.explanation: The supply issue has both HIGH impact (oxygen = survival) and HIGH urgency (shortage in 3 days). Altitude sickness is important but not yet critical. Team friction is real but doesn't stop the climb now. Prioritize by impact + urgency, not just visibility.
insights.pmbokSupport: Issues must be assessed for both probability and impact on project success

insights.explanation: Issues become risks if ignored, or they become reality. Catching supply shortage early lets you take action NOW. Altitude sickness can be monitored; team friction can wait for evening camp discussion.
insights.pmbokSupport: Proactive issue management prevents escalation to crises

trapSection.explanation: Not all issues require immediate action‚Äîdistinguish between visible, urgent, and actually blocking the mission.

trapTable.violation: Real issue, but monitoring + adjustment is the response, not immediate crisis intervention
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Confusing visible/emotional issues with time-critical impact

trapTable.violation: Important for morale, but team is still climbing effectively

checklist: Does this issue have TIME-CRITICAL impact?
Will delaying action make it worse?
What's the cascade effect if we ignore it?
Is this blocking the climb or just uncomfortable?
patternRecognition.patternRule: Time-critical + High-impact issue ‚Üí Act now. Important but not time-sensitive ‚Üí Plan response. Comfort issues ‚Üí Schedule for when time allows.

coreFramework.frameworkIntro: Managing issues requires systematic identification, assessment, and resolution‚Äîmuch like planning the ascent of a mountain summit:

rows.action: Continuously identify emerging issues through team communication, stakeholder feedback, and risk monitoring. Surface problems early before they escalate.
keyQuestions: Are we hearing concerns from the team?
rows.examKeywords: Identify issues, Surface problems, Early warning, Scan environment

rows.action: Don't just fix symptoms‚Äîdiagnose why the issue exists. Assess impact on schedule, budget, quality, and stakeholders. Determine priority.
rows.examKeywords: Root cause analysis, Impact assessment, Stakeholder analysis, Probability

rows.action: Develop solution options: mitigate, escalate, accept, or contingency. Choose strategy based on impact and urgency.
keyQuestions: Do we escalate or resolve locally?
rows.examKeywords: Mitigation strategy, Contingency plan, Escalation, Response options

rows.action: Assign ownership, set timeline, execute plan. Communicate changes to stakeholders. Don't just identify‚ÄîACT.
Track resolution. Monitor for new issues spawned by the fix. Ensure action stays on track.
keyQuestions: Did the fix cause new issues?

rows.action: Once resolved, document what happened and how you fixed it. Share with team so this issue doesn't recur. Update processes.
rows.examKeywords: Lessons learned, Process improvement, Documentation, Root cause prevention

pmbokConnection.principle: Principle 3: Focus on Value & Principle 7: Manage Stakeholder Engagement
pmbokConnection.quote: Issues are unresolved items that require management intervention. Proactive issue management prevents minor problems from becoming major blockers.

visualReferenceCard.quickReference: **Escalate:** Time-critical + high impact | **Monitor:** Important but not urgent | **Accept:** Low impact | **Contingency:** Unknown resolution path
visualReferenceCard.goldenRule: The faster you identify and respond to issues, the less damage they do. Ignore an issue, and it becomes a crisis.
visualReferenceCard.examTip: Look for 'issue,' 'problem,' 'concern,' 'risk materialized' ‚Üí Assess impact + urgency ‚Üí Choose response (mitigate, escalate, accept, contingency)
visualReferenceCard.pmbokPrinciple: Proactive Issue Management - Identify Early, Act Fast

secondScenario.title: Apply S.U.M.M.I.T.
secondScenario.scenarioStory: Three weeks into your project, a critical issue surfaces: A key vendor hasn't delivered their component yet (promised week 2, now week 3). Your team is blocked from final assembly. The vendor promises delivery 'next week' but has been vague. In parallel, your junior developer reported she's struggling with the learning curve on your new technology stack, but she's still meeting her sprint commitments.
secondScenario.question: How do you apply S.U.M.M.I.T.?

options.A: Focus on vendor issue (high impact) + mentoring the junior dev (good morale builder) in parallel
options.B: Escalate vendor immediately, negotiate a recovery plan, and setup daily check-ins; schedule dev mentoring for when we're not blocked
options.C: Accept the vendor delay as beyond your control; focus on supporting the junior dev to prevent her from burning out
options.D: Tell vendor to deliver on time or face penalties; that should motivate them

quotes.text: Issues are risks that have happened or are happening. Your job as PM is not to ignore them or hope they go away‚Äîit's to surface them, understand them, respond to them, and prevent them from happening again.
quotes.author: Coursera PMP Course

quotes.text: Issues are unresolved matters that require attention and decision-making by the project manager. Early identification and proactive management can prevent issues from becoming risks or escalating into crises.
quotes.author: PMI

fieldInsights.title: The Issue Management Trap
fieldInsights.insight: Many PMs wait for issues to be reported formally‚Äîmeetings, tickets, etc. Great PMs constantly ask: 'What could go wrong? What's brewing under the surface? What do I need to know?' Early surface = early action = less damage.

personalApplication.valueStatement: Great PMs don't prevent all issues‚Äîthey prevent issues from becoming crises by managing them early.

memoryPalace.title: Memory Palace: The Expedition Issue Station

story.title: Reaching Summit Through Issue Management
story.narrative: You're at Base Camp monitoring expedition health, **S.U.M.M.I.T.** your way to the peak...

scenes.description: Scout reports a crevasse opening on the planned route (issue surfaced early). Radio check reveals oxygen gauge malfunctioning (another issue). Morning weather forecast shows storm possible in 2 days (emerging issue). Surface = listen, observe, ask.

Analyze each: Crevasse forces route change (major impact, urgent). Broken gauge means we manually track O2 (workaround available, medium impact). Storm in 2 days (high uncertainty, plan contingency). Understand BEFORE acting.
Route change: Call mountain guide, assess alternate paths. Gauge: Implement manual tracking system. Storm: Pack up camp, wait it out OR accelerate ascent. Choose response based on impact, not panic.
Assign guide to lead route survey. Assign climber to manage manual O2 tracking. Set contingency time for storm. Communicate updated plan to team. Not just planning‚ÄîACTING.
Daily check-ins: Is guide finding safe route? Is O2 tracking accurate? Is weather prediction still holding? Any new issues appearing? Monitor, don't assume it's solved.
Once resolved: Why did crevasse open? Document new route for next expedition. Update O2 maintenance checklist. Brief team on how we responded. Prevention mindset.

story.moral: Expedition leaders **S**urface issues early, **U**nderstand their impact, **M**ap response strategies, **M**obilize action teams, **I**nspect progress, and **T**each lessons to the whole team.
